ggplot2 can not draw true 3D surfaces, but you can use geom_contour(),
geom_contour_filled(), and geom_tile() to visualise 3D surfaces in 2D.
ec: stat_contour(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "contour", position = "identity", ..., bins = NULL, binwidth = NULL, breaks = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Good labels are critical for making your plots accessible to a wider
audience. Always ensure the axis and legend labels display the full
variable name. Use the plot title and subtitle to explain the
main findings. It's common to use the caption to provide information
about the data source. tag can be used for adding identification tags
to differentiate between multiple plots.

Each geom has an associated function that draws the key when the geom needs
to be displayed in a legend. These functions are called <U+2060>draw_key_*()<U+2060>, where
* stands for the name of the respective key glyph. The key glyphs can be
customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

Divides the plane into regular hexagons, counts the number of cases in
each hexagon, and then (by default) maps the number of cases to the hexagon
fill.  Hexagon bins avoid the visual artefacts sometimes generated by
the very regular alignment of geom_bin_2d().
ec: geom_hex(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "binhex", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
The scales scale_colour_continuous() and scale_fill_continuous() are
the default colour scales ggplot2 uses when continuous data values are
mapped onto the colour or fill aesthetics, respectively. The scales
scale_colour_binned() and scale_fill_binned() are equivalent scale
functions that assign discrete color bins to the continuous values
instead of using a continuous color spectrum.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

scale_x_discrete() and scale_y_discrete() are used to set the values for
discrete x and y scale aesthetics. For simple manipulation of scale labels
and limits, you may wish to use labs() and lims() instead.
ec: scale_x_discrete(name = waiver(), ..., expand = waiver(), guide = waiver(), position = "bottom")

d:
Each geom has an associated function that draws the key when the geom needs
to be displayed in a legend. These functions are called <U+2060>draw_key_*()<U+2060>, where
* stands for the name of the respective key glyph. The key glyphs can be
customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

<U+2060>scale_*_gradient<U+2060> creates a two colour gradient (low-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradient2<U+2060> creates a diverging colour gradient (low-mid-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradientn<U+2060> creates a n-colour gradient. For binned variants of
these scales, see the color steps scales.
ec: scale_color_date(name = waiver(), ..., low = "#132B43", high = "#56B1F7", space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar")

d:
The Cartesian coordinate system is the most familiar, and common, type of
coordinate system. Setting limits on the coordinate system will zoom the
plot (like you're looking at it with a magnifying glass), and will not
change the underlying data like setting limits on a scale will.
ec: coord_cartesian(xlim = NULL, ylim = NULL, expand = TRUE, default = FALSE, clip = "on")

d:
In conjunction with the theme system, the element_ functions
specify the display of how non-data components of the plot are drawn.

Aids the eye in seeing patterns in the presence of overplotting.
geom_smooth() and stat_smooth() are effectively aliases: they
both use the same arguments. Use stat_smooth() if you want to
display the results with a non-standard geom.
ec: stat_smooth(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "smooth", position = "identity", ..., method = NULL, formula = NULL, se = TRUE, n = 80, span = 0.75, fullrange = FALSE, xseq = NULL, level = 0.95, method.args = list(), na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
label_bquote() offers a flexible way of labelling
facet rows or columns with plotmath expressions. Backquoted
variables will be replaced with their value in the facet.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Perform a 2D kernel density estimation using MASS::kde2d() and
display the results with contours. This can be useful for dealing with
overplotting. This is a 2D version of geom_density(). geom_density_2d()
draws contour lines, and geom_density_2d_filled() draws filled contour
bands.
ec: stat_density_2d(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "density_2d", position = "identity", ..., contour = TRUE, contour_var = "density", n = 100, h = NULL, adjust = c(1, 1), na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
geom_path() connects the observations in the order in which they appear
in the data. geom_line() connects them in order of the variable on the
x axis. geom_step() creates a stairstep plot, highlighting exactly
when changes occur. The group aesthetic determines which cases are
connected together.
ec: geom_path(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., lineend = "butt", linejoin = "round", linemitre = 10, arrow = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

This is a polar parameterisation of geom_segment(). It is
useful when you have variables that describe direction and distance.
The angles start from east and increase counterclockwise.
ec: geom_spoke(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
get_guide_data() builds a plot and extracts information from guide keys. This
information typically contains positions, values and/or labels, depending
on which aesthetic is queried or guide is used.

These geoms add reference lines (sometimes called rules) to a plot, either
horizontal, vertical, or diagonal (specified by slope and intercept).
These are useful for annotating plots.
ec: geom_abline(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, ..., slope, intercept, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA)

d:
This fits a quantile regression to the data and draws the fitted quantiles
with lines. This is as a continuous analogue to geom_boxplot().
ec: geom_quantile(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "quantile", position = "identity", ..., lineend = "butt", linejoin = "round", linemitre = 10, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
The scales scale_colour_continuous() and scale_fill_continuous() are
the default colour scales ggplot2 uses when continuous data values are
mapped onto the colour or fill aesthetics, respectively. The scales
scale_colour_binned() and scale_fill_binned() are equivalent scale
functions that assign discrete color bins to the continuous values
instead of using a continuous color spectrum.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

This is a variant geom_point() that counts the number of
observations at each location, then maps the count to point area. It
useful when you have discrete data and overplotting.
ec: stat_sum(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "point", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

autoplot() uses ggplot2 to draw a particular plot for an object of a
particular class in a single command. This defines the S3 generic that
other classes and packages can extend.

A violin plot is a compact display of a continuous distribution. It is a
blend of geom_boxplot() and geom_density(): a
violin plot is a mirrored density plot displayed in the same way as a
boxplot.
ec: geom_violin(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "ydensity", position = "dodge", ..., draw_quantiles = NULL, trim = TRUE, bounds = c(-Inf, Inf), scale = "area", na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
scale_linewidth scales the width of lines and polygon strokes. Due to
historical reasons, it is also possible to control this with the size
aesthetic, but using linewidth is encourage to clearly differentiate area
aesthetics from stroke width aesthetics.
ec: scale_linewidth_continuous(name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(), limits = NULL, range = c(1, 6), transform = "identity", trans = deprecated(), guide = "legend")

d:
Use this set of scales when your data has already been scaled, i.e. it
already represents aesthetic values that ggplot2 can handle directly.
These scales will not produce a legend unless you also supply the breaks,
labels, and type of guide you want.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

scale_shape() maps discrete variables to six easily discernible shapes.
If you have more than six levels, you will get a warning message, and the
seventh and subsequent levels will not appear on the plot. Use
scale_shape_manual() to supply your own values. You can not map
a continuous variable to shape unless scale_shape_binned() is used. Still,
as shape has no inherent order, this use is not advised.

This is a quick and dirty way to get map data (from the maps package)
onto your plot. This is a good place to start if you need some crude
reference lines, but you'll typically want something more sophisticated
for communication graphics.
ec: borders(database = "world", regions = ".", fill = NA, colour = "grey50", xlim = NULL, ylim = NULL, ...)

d: Convenience function to transform all position variables.

These functions are what underpins the ability of certain geoms to work
automatically in both directions. See the Extending ggplot2 vignette for
how they are used when implementing Geom, Stat, and Position classes.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

The brewer scales provide sequential, diverging and qualitative
colour schemes from ColorBrewer. These are particularly well suited to
display discrete values on a map. See https://colorbrewer2.org for
more information.
ec: scale_color_brewer(name = waiver(), ..., type = "seq", palette = 1, direction = 1, aesthetics = "colour")

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Legend type guide shows key (i.e., geoms) mapped onto values.
Legend guides for various scales are integrated if possible.
ec: guide_legend(title = waiver(), theme = NULL, position = NULL, direction = NULL, override.aes = list(), nrow = NULL, ncol = NULL, reverse = FALSE, order = 0, ...)

d:
scale_x_continuous() and scale_y_continuous() are the default
scales for continuous x and y aesthetics. There are three variants
that set the transform argument for commonly used transformations:
<U+2060>scale_*_log10()<U+2060>, <U+2060>scale_*_sqrt()<U+2060> and <U+2060>scale_*_reverse()<U+2060>.

These functions allow you to specify your own set of mappings from levels in the
data to aesthetic values.
ec: scale_size_manual(..., values, breaks = waiver(), na.value = NA)

d:
The polar coordinate system is most commonly used for pie charts, which
are a stacked bar chart in polar coordinates. coord_radial() has extended
options.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

A fixed scale coordinate system forces a specified ratio between the
physical representation of data units on the axes. The ratio represents the
number of units on the y-axis equivalent to one unit on the x-axis. The
default, ratio = 1, ensures that one unit on the x-axis is the same
length as one unit on the y-axis. Ratios higher than one make units on the
y axis longer than units on the x-axis, and vice versa. This is similar to
MASS::eqscplot(), but it works for all types of graphics.
ec: coord_fixed(ratio = 1, xlim = NULL, ylim = NULL, expand = TRUE, clip = "on")

d: Arrange 1d structure into a grid

scale_size() scales area, scale_radius() scales radius. The size
aesthetic is most commonly used for points and text, and humans perceive
the area of points (not their radius), so this provides for optimal
perception. scale_size_area() ensures that a value of 0 is mapped
to a size of 0. scale_size_binned() is a binned version of scale_size() that
scales by area (but does not ensure 0 equals an area of zero). For a binned
equivalent of scale_size_area() use scale_size_binned_area().

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

<U+2060>scale_*_gradient<U+2060> creates a two colour gradient (low-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradient2<U+2060> creates a diverging colour gradient (low-mid-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradientn<U+2060> creates a n-colour gradient. For binned variants of
these scales, see the color steps scales.
ec: scale_colour_gradient(name = waiver(), ..., low = "#132B43", high = "#56B1F7", space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar", aesthetics = "colour")

d:
These functions allow you to specify your own set of mappings from levels in the
data to aesthetic values.
ec: scale_linewidth_manual(..., values, breaks = waiver(), na.value = NA)

d:
The scales scale_colour_continuous() and scale_fill_continuous() are
the default colour scales ggplot2 uses when continuous data values are
mapped onto the colour or fill aesthetics, respectively. The scales
scale_colour_binned() and scale_fill_binned() are equivalent scale
functions that assign discrete color bins to the continuous values
instead of using a continuous color spectrum.

Divides the plane into rectangles, counts the number of cases in
each rectangle, and then (by default) maps the number of cases to the
rectangle's fill. This is a useful alternative to geom_point()
in the presence of overplotting.
ec: stat_bin_2d(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "tile", position = "identity", ..., bins = 30, binwidth = NULL, drop = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Use this set of scales when your data has already been scaled, i.e. it
already represents aesthetic values that ggplot2 can handle directly.
These scales will not produce a legend unless you also supply the breaks,
labels, and type of guide you want.

Aesthetic mappings describe how variables in the data are mapped to visual
properties (aesthetics) of geoms. Aesthetic mappings can be set in
ggplot() and in individual layers.

In conjunction with the theme system, the element_ functions
specify the display of how non-data components of the plot are drawn.
ec: element_rect(fill = NULL, colour = NULL, linewidth = NULL, linetype = NULL, color = NULL, inherit.blank = FALSE, size = deprecated())

d:
qplot() is now deprecated in order to encourage the users to
learn ggplot() as it makes it easier to create complex graphics.
ec: quickplot(x, y, ..., data, facets = NULL, margins = FALSE, geom = "auto", xlim = c(NA, NA), ylim = c(NA, NA), log = "", main = NULL, xlab = NULL, ylab = NULL, asp = NA, stat = deprecated(), position = deprecated())

d:
Most aesthetics are mapped from variables found in the data.
Sometimes, however, you want to delay the mapping until later in the
rendering process. ggplot2 has three stages of the data that you can map
aesthetics from, and three functions to control at which stage aesthetics
should be evaluated.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

These geoms add reference lines (sometimes called rules) to a plot, either
horizontal, vertical, or diagonal (specified by slope and intercept).
These are useful for annotating plots.
ec: geom_hline(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, ..., yintercept, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA)

d:
Each geom has an associated function that draws the key when the geom needs
to be displayed in a legend. These functions are called <U+2060>draw_key_*()<U+2060>, where
* stands for the name of the respective key glyph. The key glyphs can be
customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

scale_size() scales area, scale_radius() scales radius. The size
aesthetic is most commonly used for points and text, and humans perceive
the area of points (not their radius), so this provides for optimal
perception. scale_size_area() ensures that a value of 0 is mapped
to a size of 0. scale_size_binned() is a binned version of scale_size() that
scales by area (but does not ensure 0 equals an area of zero). For a binned
equivalent of scale_size_area() use scale_size_binned_area().

In conjunction with the theme system, the element_ functions
specify the display of how non-data components of the plot are drawn.

Each geom has an associated function that draws the key when the geom needs
to be displayed in a legend. These functions are called <U+2060>draw_key_*()<U+2060>, where
* stands for the name of the respective key glyph. The key glyphs can be
customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

Given a theme object and element name, returns a grob for the element.
Uses element_grob() to generate the grob.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,

* stands for the name of the respective key glyph. The key glyphs can be
customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

This is a convenience function for generating scale expansion vectors
for the expand argument of scale_(x|y)_continuous
and scale_(x|y)_discrete. The expansion vectors are used to
add some space between the data and the axes.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

specify the display of how non-data components of the plot are drawn.

<U+2060>scale_*_gradient<U+2060> creates a two colour gradient (low-high),

<U+2060>scale_*_gradientn<U+2060> creates a n-colour gradient. For binned variants of
these scales, see the color steps scales.
ec: scale_fill_date(name = waiver(), ..., low = "#132B43", high = "#56B1F7", space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar")

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Labeller functions are in charge of formatting the strip labels of
facet grids and wraps. Most of them accept a multi_line
argument to control whether multiple factors (defined in formulae
such as ~first + second) should be displayed on a single
line separated with commas, or each on their own line.

The brewer scales provide sequential, diverging and qualitative
colour schemes from ColorBrewer. These are particularly well suited to
display discrete values on a map. See https://colorbrewer2.org for
more information.
ec: scale_color_distiller(name = waiver(), ..., type = "seq", palette = 1, direction = -1, values = NULL, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar", aesthetics = "colour")

d:
For each x value, geom_ribbon() displays a y interval defined
by ymin and ymax. geom_area() is a special case of
geom_ribbon(), where the ymin is fixed to 0 and y is used instead
of ymax.
ec: geom_ribbon(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE, outline.type = "both")

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Computes and draws a function as a continuous curve. This makes it easy to
superimpose a function on top of an existing plot. The function is called
with a grid of evenly spaced values along the x axis, and the results are
drawn (by default) with a line.
ec: stat_function(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "function", position = "identity", ..., fun, xlim = NULL, n = 101, args = list(), na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
facet_grid() forms a matrix of panels defined by row and column
faceting variables. It is most useful when you have two discrete
variables, and all combinations of the variables exist in the data.
If you have only one variable with many levels, try facet_wrap().
ec: facet_grid(rows = NULL, cols = NULL, scales = "fixed", space = "fixed", shrink = TRUE, labeller = "label_value", as.table = TRUE, switch = NULL, drop = TRUE, margins = FALSE, axes = "margins", axis.labels = "all", facets = deprecated())

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

These functions are what underpins the ability of certain geoms to work
automatically in both directions. See the Extending ggplot2 vignette for
how they are used when implementing Geom, Stat, and Position classes.
ec: has_flipped_aes(data, params = list(), main_is_orthogonal = NA, range_is_orthogonal = NA, group_has_equal = FALSE, ambiguous = FALSE, main_is_continuous = FALSE, main_is_optional = FALSE)

d:
This transforms objects to labeller functions. Used internally by
labeller().

Use this set of scales when your data has already been scaled, i.e. it
already represents aesthetic values that ggplot2 can handle directly.
These scales will not produce a legend unless you also supply the breaks,
labels, and type of guide you want.

Divides the plane into rectangles, counts the number of cases in
each rectangle, and then (by default) maps the number of cases to the
rectangle's fill. This is a useful alternative to geom_point()
in the presence of overplotting.
ec: geom_bin2d(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "bin2d", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
A violin plot is a compact display of a continuous distribution. It is a
blend of geom_boxplot() and geom_density(): a
violin plot is a mirrored density plot displayed in the same way as a
boxplot.
ec: stat_ydensity(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "violin", position = "dodge", ..., bw = "nrd0", adjust = 1, kernel = "gaussian", trim = TRUE, scale = "area", drop = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE, bounds = c(-Inf, Inf))

d:
ggplot2 can not draw true 3D surfaces, but you can use geom_contour(),
geom_contour_filled(), and geom_tile() to visualise 3D surfaces in 2D.
ec: geom_contour_filled(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "contour_filled", position = "identity", ..., bins = NULL, binwidth = NULL, breaks = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Maps each level to an evenly spaced hue on the colour wheel.
It does not generate colour-blind safe palettes.
ec: scale_colour_hue(name = waiver(), ..., h = c(0, 360) + 15, c = 100, l = 65, h.start = 0, direction = 1, na.value = "grey50", aesthetics = "colour")

d:
These are complete themes which control all non-data display. Use
theme() if you just need to tweak the display of an existing
theme.
ec: theme_classic(base_size = 11, base_family = "", base_line_size = base_size/22, base_rect_size = base_size/22)

d:
Polygons are very similar to paths (as drawn by geom_path())
except that the start and end points are connected and the inside is
coloured by fill. The group aesthetic determines which cases
are connected together into a polygon. From R 3.6 and onwards it is possible
to draw polygons with holes by providing a subgroup aesthetic that
differentiates the outer ring points from those describing holes in the
polygon.
ec: geom_polygon(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", rule = "evenodd", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d: These functions provide summarised information about built ggplot objects.

geom_rect() and geom_tile() do the same thing, but are
parameterised differently: geom_rect() uses the locations of the four
corners (xmin, xmax, ymin and ymax), while
geom_tile() uses the center of the tile and its size (x,
y, width, height). geom_raster() is a high
performance special case for when all the tiles are the same size, and no
pattern fills are applied.
ec: geom_tile(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., linejoin = "mitre", na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

These functions allow you to specify your own set of mappings from levels in the
data to aesthetic values.
ec: scale_color_manual(..., values, aesthetics = "colour", breaks = waiver(), na.value = "grey50")

d:
<U+2060>scale_*_steps<U+2060> creates a two colour binned gradient (low-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_steps2<U+2060> creates a diverging binned colour gradient (low-mid-high),
and <U+2060>scale_*_stepsn<U+2060> creates a n-colour binned gradient. These scales are
binned variants of the gradient scale family and
works in the same way.
ec: scale_color_stepsn(name = waiver(), ..., colours, values = NULL, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "coloursteps", aesthetics = "colour", colors)

d:
Perform a 2D kernel density estimation using MASS::kde2d() and
display the results with contours. This can be useful for dealing with
overplotting. This is a 2D version of geom_density(). geom_density_2d()
draws contour lines, and geom_density_2d_filled() draws filled contour
bands.
ec: stat_density2d(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "density_2d", position = "identity", ..., contour = TRUE, contour_var = "density", n = 100, h = NULL, adjust = c(1, 1), na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Default line types based on a set supplied by Richard Pearson,
University of Manchester. Continuous values can not be mapped to
line types unless scale_linetype_binned() is used. Still, as linetypes has
no inherent order, this use is not advised.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

ggplot_build() takes the plot object, and performs all steps necessary
to produce an object that can be rendered.  This function outputs two pieces:
a list of data frames (one for each layer), and a panel object, which
contain all information about axis limits, breaks etc.

The method for calculating the ellipses has been modified from
car::dataEllipse (Fox and Weisberg 2011, Friendly and Monette 2013)
ec: stat_ellipse(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "path", position = "identity", ..., type = "t", level = 0.95, segments = 51, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:

mapped onto the colour or fill aesthetics, respectively. The scales

Various ways of representing a vertical interval defined by x,
ymin and ymax. Each case draws a single graphical object.
ec: geom_errorbar(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

This is a polar parameterisation of geom_segment(). It is
useful when you have variables that describe direction and distance.
The angles start from east and increase counterclockwise.
Generate grid grob from theme element

d:
This function builds all grobs necessary for displaying the plot, and
stores them in a special data structure called a gtable().
This object is amenable to programmatic manipulation, should you want
to (e.g.) make the legend box 2 cm wide, or combine multiple plots into
a single display, preserving aspect ratios across the plots.

geom_qq() and stat_qq() produce quantile-quantile plots. geom_qq_line() and
stat_qq_line() compute the slope and intercept of the line connecting the
points at specified quartiles of the theoretical and sample distributions.
ec: geom_qq(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "point", position = "identity", ..., distribution = stats::qnorm, dparams = list(), na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

ec: binned_scale(aesthetics, scale_name = deprecated(), palette, name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(), limits = NULL, rescaler = rescale, oob = squish, expand = waiver(), na.value = NA_real_, n.breaks = NULL, nice.breaks = TRUE, right = TRUE, transform = "identity", trans = deprecated(), show.limits = FALSE, guide = "bins", position = "left", call = caller_call(), super = ScaleBinned)

stat_summary() operates on unique x or y; stat_summary_bin()
operates on binned x or y. They are more flexible versions of
stat_bin(): instead of just counting, they can compute any
aggregate.
ec: stat_summary_bin(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "pointrange", position = "identity", ..., fun.data = NULL, fun = NULL, fun.max = NULL, fun.min = NULL, fun.args = list(), bins = 30, binwidth = NULL, breaks = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE, fun.y = deprecated(), fun.ymin = deprecated(), fun.ymax = deprecated())

Calculate the element properties, by inheriting properties from its parents
ec: calc_element(element, theme, verbose = FALSE, skip_blank = FALSE, call = caller_env())

d:
A layer is a combination of data, stat and geom with a potential position
adjustment. Usually layers are created using <U+2060>geom_*<U+2060> or <U+2060>stat_*<U+2060>
calls but it can also be created directly using this function.
ec: layer(geom = NULL, stat = NULL, data = NULL, mapping = NULL, position = NULL, params = list(), inherit.aes = TRUE, check.aes = TRUE, check.param = TRUE, show.legend = NA, key_glyph = NULL, layer_class = Layer)

d:
The guide system has been overhauled to use the ggproto infrastructure to
accommodate guide extensions with the same flexibility as layers, scales and
other ggplot2 objects. In rewriting, the old S3 system has become defunct,
meaning that the previous methods for guides have been superseded by ggproto
methods. As a fallback option, the generics, but not the methods, that the
previous S3 system used are encapsulated in the GuideOld ggproto class.

Axis guides are the visual representation of position scales like those
created with scale_(x|y)_continuous() and
scale_(x|y)_discrete().
ec: guide_axis(title = waiver(), theme = NULL, check.overlap = FALSE, angle = waiver(), n.dodge = 1, minor.ticks = FALSE, cap = "none", order = 0, position = waiver())

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

This is a special version of geom_raster() optimised for static
annotations that are the same in every panel. These annotations will not
affect scales (i.e. the x and y axes will not grow to cover the range
of the raster, and the raster must already have its own colours). This
is useful for adding bitmap images.
ec: annotation_raster(raster, xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax, interpolate = FALSE)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

scale_x_continuous() and scale_y_continuous() are the default
scales for continuous x and y aesthetics. There are three variants
that set the transform argument for commonly used transformations:
<U+2060>scale_*_log10()<U+2060>, <U+2060>scale_*_sqrt()<U+2060> and <U+2060>scale_*_reverse()<U+2060>.

The brewer scales provide sequential, diverging and qualitative
colour schemes from ColorBrewer. These are particularly well suited to
display discrete values on a map. See https://colorbrewer2.org for
more information.
ec: scale_colour_brewer(name = waiver(), ..., type = "seq", palette = 1, direction = 1, aesthetics = "colour")

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

<U+2060>scale_*_gradient<U+2060> creates a two colour gradient (low-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradient2<U+2060> creates a diverging colour gradient (low-mid-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradientn<U+2060> creates a n-colour gradient. For binned variants of
these scales, see the color steps scales.
ec: scale_fill_datetime(name = waiver(), ..., low = "#132B43", high = "#56B1F7", space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar")

d:
This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
ec: dup_axis(transform = ~., name = derive(), breaks = derive(), labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated())

d:
The guide system has been overhauled to use the ggproto infrastructure to
accommodate guide extensions with the same flexibility as layers, scales and
other ggplot2 objects. In rewriting, the old S3 system has become defunct,
meaning that the previous methods for guides have been superseded by ggproto
methods. As a fallback option, the generics, but not the methods, that the
previous S3 system used are encapsulated in the GuideOld ggproto class.

<U+2060>scale_*_steps<U+2060> creates a two colour binned gradient (low-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_steps2<U+2060> creates a diverging binned colour gradient (low-mid-high),
and <U+2060>scale_*_stepsn<U+2060> creates a n-colour binned gradient. These scales are
binned variants of the gradient scale family and
works in the same way.
ec: scale_fill_stepsn(name = waiver(), ..., colours, values = NULL, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "coloursteps", aesthetics = "fill", colors)

d: Reports whether x is a ggplot object

The default discrete colour scale. Defaults to scale_fill_hue()/scale_fill_brewer()
unless type (which defaults to the ggplot2.discrete.fill/ggplot2.discrete.colour options)
is specified.

For each x value, geom_ribbon() displays a y interval defined
by ymin and ymax. geom_area() is a special case of
geom_ribbon(), where the ymin is fixed to 0 and y is used instead
of ymax.
ec: geom_area(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "align", position = "stack", na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE, ..., outline.type = "upper")

d:
The viridis scales provide colour maps that are perceptually uniform in both
colour and black-and-white. They are also designed to be perceived by viewers
with common forms of colour blindness. See also
https://bids.github.io/colormap/.
ec: scale_fill_viridis_b(name = waiver(), ..., alpha = 1, begin = 0, end = 1, direction = 1, option = "D", values = NULL, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "coloursteps", aesthetics = "fill")

d:
scale_linewidth scales the width of lines and polygon strokes. Due to
historical reasons, it is also possible to control this with the size
aesthetic, but using linewidth is encourage to clearly differentiate area
aesthetics from stroke width aesthetics.

This set of geom, stat, and coord are used to visualise simple feature (sf)
objects. For simple plots, you will only need geom_sf() as it
uses stat_sf() and adds coord_sf() for you. geom_sf() is
an unusual geom because it will draw different geometric objects depending
on what simple features are present in the data: you can get points, lines,
or polygons.
For text and labels, you can use geom_sf_text() and geom_sf_label().
ec: geom_sf(mapping = aes(), data = NULL, stat = "sf", position = "identity", na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE, ...)

d:
The viridis scales provide colour maps that are perceptually uniform in both
colour and black-and-white. They are also designed to be perceived by viewers
with common forms of colour blindness. See also
https://bids.github.io/colormap/.
ec: scale_fill_viridis_c(name = waiver(), ..., alpha = 1, begin = 0, end = 1, direction = 1, option = "D", values = NULL, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar", aesthetics = "fill")

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

The viridis scales provide colour maps that are perceptually uniform in both
colour and black-and-white. They are also designed to be perceived by viewers
with common forms of colour blindness. See also
https://bids.github.io/colormap/.
ec: scale_fill_viridis_d(name = waiver(), ..., alpha = 1, begin = 0, end = 1, direction = 1, option = "D", aesthetics = "fill")

d: Get the maximal width/length of a list of grobs

scale_shape() maps discrete variables to six easily discernible shapes.
If you have more than six levels, you will get a warning message, and the
seventh and subsequent levels will not appear on the plot. Use
scale_shape_manual() to supply your own values. You can not map
a continuous variable to shape unless scale_shape_binned() is used. Still,
as shape has no inherent order, this use is not advised.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

For each x value, geom_ribbon() displays a y interval defined
by ymin and ymax. geom_area() is a special case of
geom_ribbon(), where the ymin is fixed to 0 and y is used instead
of ymax.
ec: stat_align(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "area", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
facet_wrap() wraps a 1d sequence of panels into 2d. This is generally
a better use of screen space than facet_grid() because most
displays are roughly rectangular.
ec: facet_wrap(facets, nrow = NULL, ncol = NULL, scales = "fixed", shrink = TRUE, labeller = "label_value", as.table = TRUE, switch = deprecated(), drop = TRUE, dir = "h", strip.position = "top", axes = "margins", axis.labels = "all")

d:
A rug plot is a compact visualisation designed to supplement a 2d display
with the two 1d marginal distributions. Rug plots display individual
cases so are best used with smaller datasets.
ec: geom_rug(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., outside = FALSE, sides = "bl", length = unit(0.03, "npc"), na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
These are complete themes which control all non-data display. Use
theme() if you just need to tweak the display of an existing
theme.
ec: theme_test(base_size = 11, base_family = "", base_line_size = base_size/22, base_rect_size = base_size/22)

d:
These are complete themes which control all non-data display. Use
theme() if you just need to tweak the display of an existing
theme.
ec: theme_linedraw(base_size = 11, base_family = "", base_line_size = base_size/22, base_rect_size = base_size/22)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Each geom has an associated function that draws the key when the geom needs
to be displayed in a legend. These functions are called <U+2060>draw_key_*()<U+2060>, where
* stands for the name of the respective key glyph. The key glyphs can be
customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

The brewer scales provide sequential, diverging and qualitative
colour schemes from ColorBrewer. These are particularly well suited to
display discrete values on a map. See https://colorbrewer2.org for
more information.
ec: scale_colour_distiller(name = waiver(), ..., type = "seq", palette = 1, direction = -1, values = NULL, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar", aesthetics = "colour")

d:
Labeller functions are in charge of formatting the strip labels of
facet grids and wraps. Most of them accept a multi_line
argument to control whether multiple factors (defined in formulae
such as ~first + second) should be displayed on a single
line separated with commas, or each on their own line.
For use with stat_summary()

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Construct a new object with ggproto(), test with is.ggproto(),
and access parent methods/fields with ggproto_parent().

scale_x_continuous() and scale_y_continuous() are the default
scales for continuous x and y aesthetics. There are three variants
that set the transform argument for commonly used transformations:
<U+2060>scale_*_log10()<U+2060>, <U+2060>scale_*_sqrt()<U+2060> and <U+2060>scale_*_reverse()<U+2060>.

The viridis scales provide colour maps that are perceptually uniform in both
colour and black-and-white. They are also designed to be perceived by viewers
with common forms of colour blindness. See also
https://bids.github.io/colormap/.

There are two types of bar charts: geom_bar() and geom_col().
geom_bar() makes the height of the bar proportional to the number of
cases in each group (or if the weight aesthetic is supplied, the sum
of the weights). If you want the heights of the bars to represent values
in the data, use geom_col() instead. geom_bar() uses stat_count() by
default: it counts the number of cases at each x position. geom_col()
uses stat_identity(): it leaves the data as is.
ec: geom_bar(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "count", position = "stack", ..., just = 0.5, width = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Sometimes you may want to ensure limits include a single value, for all
panels or all plots.  This function is a thin wrapper around
geom_blank() that makes it easy to add such values.

The brewer scales provide sequential, diverging and qualitative
colour schemes from ColorBrewer. These are particularly well suited to
display discrete values on a map. See https://colorbrewer2.org for
more information.
ec: scale_fill_brewer(name = waiver(), ..., type = "seq", palette = 1, direction = 1, aesthetics = "fill")

d:
This function makes an attempt to estimate whether the graphics device is
able to render newer graphics features.
ec: check_device(feature, action = "warn", op = NULL, maybe = FALSE, call = caller_env())

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Each geom has an associated function that draws the key when the geom needs
to be displayed in a legend. These functions are called <U+2060>draw_key_*()<U+2060>, where
* stands for the name of the respective key glyph. The key glyphs can be
customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

This set of geom, stat, and coord are used to visualise simple feature (sf)
objects. For simple plots, you will only need geom_sf() as it
uses stat_sf() and adds coord_sf() for you. geom_sf() is
an unusual geom because it will draw different geometric objects depending
on what simple features are present in the data: you can get points, lines,
or polygons.
For text and labels, you can use geom_sf_text() and geom_sf_label().
ec: geom_sf_label(mapping = aes(), data = NULL, stat = "sf_coordinates", position = "identity", ..., parse = FALSE, nudge_x = 0, nudge_y = 0, label.padding = unit(0.25, "lines"), label.r = unit(0.15, "lines"), label.size = 0.25, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE, fun.geometry = NULL)

d:
This is a shortcut for supplying the limits argument to the individual
scales. By default, any values outside the limits specified are replaced with
NA. Be warned that this will remove data outside the limits and this can
produce unintended results. For changing x or y axis limits without
dropping data observations, see coord_cartesian().

The underlying structure of a ggplot2 theme is defined via the element tree, which
specifies for each theme element what type it should have and whether it inherits from
a parent element. In some use cases, it may be necessary to modify or extend this
element tree and provide default settings for newly defined theme elements.

This function "munches" lines, dividing each line into many small pieces
so they can be transformed independently. Used inside geom functions.
ec: coord_munch(coord, data, range, segment_length = 0.01, is_closed = FALSE)

d:
This guide is version of guide_colourbar() for binned colour and fill
scales. It shows areas between breaks as a single constant colour instead of
the gradient known from the colourbar counterpart.
ec: guide_colorsteps(title = waiver(), theme = NULL, alpha = NA, even.steps = TRUE, show.limits = NULL, direction = NULL, reverse = FALSE, order = 0, available_aes = c("colour", "color", "fill"), ...)

d:
scale_linewidth scales the width of lines and polygon strokes. Due to
historical reasons, it is also possible to control this with the size
aesthetic, but using linewidth is encourage to clearly differentiate area
aesthetics from stroke width aesthetics.
ec: scale_linewidth_binned(name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(), limits = NULL, range = c(1, 6), n.breaks = NULL, nice.breaks = TRUE, transform = "identity", trans = deprecated(), guide = "bins")

d:
Alpha-transparency scales are not tremendously useful, but can be a
convenient way to visually down-weight less important observations.
scale_alpha() is an alias for scale_alpha_continuous() since
that is the most common use of alpha, and it saves a bit of typing.

scale_size() scales area, scale_radius() scales radius. The size
aesthetic is most commonly used for points and text, and humans perceive
the area of points (not their radius), so this provides for optimal
perception. scale_size_area() ensures that a value of 0 is mapped
to a size of 0. scale_size_binned() is a binned version of scale_size() that
scales by area (but does not ensure 0 equals an area of zero). For a binned
equivalent of scale_size_area() use scale_size_binned_area().

<U+2060>scale_*_steps<U+2060> creates a two colour binned gradient (low-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_steps2<U+2060> creates a diverging binned colour gradient (low-mid-high),
and <U+2060>scale_*_stepsn<U+2060> creates a n-colour binned gradient. These scales are
binned variants of the gradient scale family and
works in the same way.
ec: scale_colour_steps2(name = waiver(), ..., low = muted("red"), mid = "white", high = muted("blue"), midpoint = 0, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", transform = "identity", guide = "coloursteps", aesthetics = "colour")

d:
You will need to define a method for this method if you want to extend
ggplot2 to handle new types of data. If you simply want to pass the vector
through as an additional aesthetic, return "identity".

These functions allow you to specify your own set of mappings from levels in the
data to aesthetic values.
ec: scale_colour_manual(..., values, aesthetics = "colour", breaks = waiver(), na.value = "grey50")

d:
geom_rect() and geom_tile() do the same thing, but are
parameterised differently: geom_rect() uses the locations of the four
corners (xmin, xmax, ymin and ymax), while
geom_tile() uses the center of the tile and its size (x,
y, width, height). geom_raster() is a high
performance special case for when all the tiles are the same size, and no
pattern fills are applied.
ec: geom_rect(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., linejoin = "mitre", na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
These are complete themes which control all non-data display. Use
theme() if you just need to tweak the display of an existing
theme.
ec: theme_minimal(base_size = 11, base_family = "", base_line_size = base_size/22, base_rect_size = base_size/22)

d:
<U+2060>scale_*_gradient<U+2060> creates a two colour gradient (low-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradient2<U+2060> creates a diverging colour gradient (low-mid-high),
<U+2060>scale_*_gradientn<U+2060> creates a n-colour gradient. For binned variants of
these scales, see the color steps scales.
ec: scale_color_gradientn(name = waiver(), ..., colours, values = NULL, space = "Lab", na.value = "grey50", guide = "colourbar", aesthetics = "colour", colors)

d:
Maps each level to an evenly spaced hue on the colour wheel.
It does not generate colour-blind safe palettes.
ec: scale_fill_hue(name = waiver(), ..., h = c(0, 360) + 15, c = 100, l = 65, h.start = 0, direction = 1, na.value = "grey50", aesthetics = "fill")

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.
A rotated version of geom_errorbar().
ec: geom_errorbarh(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Counterintuitively adding random noise to a plot can sometimes make it
easier to read. Jittering is particularly useful for small datasets with
at least one discrete position.
ec: position_jitter(width = NULL, height = NULL, seed = NA)

d:
geom_qq() and stat_qq() produce quantile-quantile plots. geom_qq_line() and
stat_qq_line() compute the slope and intercept of the line connecting the
points at specified quartiles of the theoretical and sample distributions.
ec: geom_qq_line(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "path", position = "identity", ..., distribution = stats::qnorm, dparams = list(), line.p = c(0.25, 0.75), fullrange = FALSE, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

meaning that the previous methods for guides have been superseded by ggproto

Colour bar guide shows continuous colour scales mapped onto values.
Colour bar is available with scale_fill and scale_colour.
For more information, see the inspiration for this function:
Matlab's colorbar function.
ec: guide_colorbar(title = waiver(), theme = NULL, nbin = NULL, display = "raster", raster = deprecated(), alpha = NA, draw.ulim = TRUE, draw.llim = TRUE, position = NULL, direction = NULL, reverse = FALSE, order = 0, available_aes = c("colour", "color", "fill"), ...)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Default line types based on a set supplied by Richard Pearson,
University of Manchester. Continuous values can not be mapped to
line types unless scale_linetype_binned() is used. Still, as linetypes has
no inherent order, this use is not advised.

These are the default scales for the three date/time class. These will
usually be added automatically. To override manually, use
<U+2060>scale_*_date<U+2060> for dates (class Date),
<U+2060>scale_*_datetime<U+2060> for datetimes (class POSIXct), and
<U+2060>scale_*_time<U+2060> for times (class hms).
ec: scale_x_date(name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), date_breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(), date_labels = waiver(), minor_breaks = waiver(), date_minor_breaks = waiver(), limits = NULL, expand = waiver(), oob = censor, guide = waiver(), position = "bottom", sec.axis = waiver())

d:
These functions allow you to specify your own set of mappings from levels in the
data to aesthetic values.
ec: scale_shape_manual(..., values, breaks = waiver(), na.value = NA)

d:
Guides for each scale can be set scale-by-scale with the guide
argument, or en masse with guides().

stat_summary_2d() is a 2d variation of stat_summary().
stat_summary_hex() is a hexagonal variation of
stat_summary_2d(). The data are divided into bins defined
by x and y, and then the values of z in each cell is
are summarised with fun.
ec: stat_summary_hex(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "hex", position = "identity", ..., bins = 30, binwidth = NULL, drop = TRUE, fun = "mean", fun.args = list(), na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
scale_size() scales area, scale_radius() scales radius. The size
aesthetic is most commonly used for points and text, and humans perceive
the area of points (not their radius), so this provides for optimal
perception. scale_size_area() ensures that a value of 0 is mapped

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

Display a fixed map on a plot. This function predates the geom_sf()
framework and does not work with sf geometry columns as input. However,
it can be used in conjunction with geom_sf() layers and/or
coord_sf() (see examples).

If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

The boxplot compactly displays the distribution of a continuous variable.
It visualises five summary statistics (the median, two hinges
and two whiskers), and all "outlying" points individually.
ec: geom_boxplot(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "boxplot", position = "dodge2", ..., outliers = TRUE, outlier.colour = NULL, outlier.color = NULL, outlier.fill = NULL, outlier.shape = 19, outlier.size = 1.5, outlier.stroke = 0.5, outlier.alpha = NULL, notch = FALSE, notchwidth = 0.5, staplewidth = 0, varwidth = FALSE, na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Most aesthetics are mapped from variables found in the data.
Sometimes, however, you want to delay the mapping until later in the
rendering process. ggplot2 has three stages of the data that you can map
aesthetics from, and three functions to control at which stage aesthetics
should be evaluated.

The empirical cumulative distribution function (ECDF) provides an alternative
visualisation of distribution. Compared to other visualisations that rely on
density (like geom_histogram()), the ECDF doesn't require any
tuning parameters and handles both continuous and categorical variables.
The downside is that it requires more training to accurately interpret,
and the underlying visual tasks are somewhat more challenging.
ec: stat_ecdf(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "step", position = "identity", ..., n = NULL, pad = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
If you are creating a new geom, stat, position, or scale in another package,
you'll need to extend from ggplot2::Geom, ggplot2::Stat,
ggplot2::Position, or ggplot2::Scale.

The current/active theme (see theme()) is automatically applied to every
plot you draw. Use theme_get() to get the current theme, and theme_set() to
completely override it. theme_update() and theme_replace() are shorthands for
changing individual elements.

This generic allows you to add your own methods for adding custom objects to
a ggplot with +.gg.

This set of geom, stat, and coord are used to visualise simple feature (sf)
objects. For simple plots, you will only need geom_sf() as it
uses stat_sf() and adds coord_sf() for you. geom_sf() is
an unusual geom because it will draw different geometric objects depending
on what simple features are present in the data: you can get points, lines,
or polygons.
For text and labels, you can use geom_sf_text() and geom_sf_label().
ec: geom_sf_text(mapping = aes(), data = NULL, stat = "sf_coordinates", position = "identity", ..., parse = FALSE, nudge_x = 0, nudge_y = 0, check_overlap = FALSE, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE, fun.geometry = NULL)

d: Update axis/legend labels

In a dot plot, the width of a dot corresponds to the bin width
(or maximum width, depending on the binning algorithm), and dots are
stacked, with each dot representing one observation.

geom_rect() and geom_tile() do the same thing, but are
parameterised differently: geom_rect() uses the locations of the four
corners (xmin, xmax, ymin and ymax), while
geom_tile() uses the center of the tile and its size (x,
y, width, height). geom_raster() is a high

pattern fills are applied.

The current/active theme (see theme()) is automatically applied to every

completely override it. theme_update() and theme_replace() are shorthands for
changing individual elements.

Themes are a powerful way to customize the non-data components of your plots:
i.e. titles, labels, fonts, background, gridlines, and legends. Themes can be
used to give plots a consistent customized look. Modify a single plot's theme
using theme(); see theme_update() if you want modify the active theme, to
affect all subsequent plots. Use the themes available in complete themes if you would like to use a complete theme such as
theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), and more. Theme elements are documented
together according to inheritance, read more about theme inheritance below.

Perform a 2D kernel density estimation using MASS::kde2d() and
display the results with contours. This can be useful for dealing with
overplotting. This is a 2D version of geom_density(). geom_density_2d()
draws contour lines, and geom_density_2d_filled() draws filled contour
bands.
ec: geom_density_2d_filled(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "density_2d_filled", position = "identity", ..., contour_var = "density", na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

Labeller functions are in charge of formatting the strip labels of
facet grids and wraps. Most of them accept a multi_line
argument to control whether multiple factors (defined in formulae
such as ~first + second) should be displayed on a single
line separated with commas, or each on their own line.

The .ignore_data() function is used to hide <U+2060><AsIs><U+2060> columns during
scale interactions in ggplot_build(). The .expose_data() function is
used to restore hidden columns.

Is this object a faceting specification?

Computes and draws a function as a continuous curve. This makes it easy to
superimpose a function on top of an existing plot. The function is called
with a grid of evenly spaced values along the x axis, and the results are
drawn (by default) with a line.
ec: geom_function(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "function", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

Good labels are critical for making your plots accessible to a wider

Benchmark plot creation time.
Broken down into construct, build, render and draw times.

Divides the plane into rectangles, counts the number of cases in
each rectangle, and then (by default) maps the number of cases to the
rectangle's fill. This is a useful alternative to geom_point()
in the presence of overplotting.
ec: stat_bin2d(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, geom = "tile", position = "identity", ..., bins = 30, binwidth = NULL, drop = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
ggsave() is a convenient function for saving a plot. It defaults to
saving the last plot that you displayed, using the size of the current
graphics device. It also guesses the type of graphics device from the
extension.
ec: ggsave(filename, plot = last_plot(), device = NULL, path = NULL, scale = 1, width = NA, height = NA, units = c("in", "cm", "mm", "px"), dpi = 300, limitsize = TRUE, bg = NULL, create.dir = FALSE, ...)

The brewer scales provide sequential, diverging and qualitative
colour schemes from ColorBrewer. These are particularly well suited to
display discrete values on a map. See https://colorbrewer2.org for
more information.
ec: scale_colour_fermenter(name = waiver(), ..., type = "seq", palette = 1, direction = -1, na.value = "grey50", guide = "coloursteps", aesthetics = "colour")

d:
The jitter geom is a convenient shortcut for
geom_point(position = "jitter"). It adds a small amount of random
variation to the location of each point, and is a useful way of handling
overplotting caused by discreteness in smaller datasets.
ec: geom_jitter(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "jitter", ..., width = NULL, height = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

scale_linewidth scales the width of lines and polygon strokes. Due to
historical reasons, it is also possible to control this with the size
aesthetic, but using linewidth is encourage to clearly differentiate area
aesthetics from stroke width aesthetics.

The underlying structure of a ggplot2 theme is defined via the element tree, which
specifies for each theme element what type it should have and whether it inherits from
a parent element. In some use cases, it may be necessary to modify or extend this
element tree and provide default settings for newly defined theme elements.

Remove all non-complete rows, with a warning if na.rm = FALSE.
ggplot is somewhat more accommodating of missing values than R generally.
For those stats which require complete data, missing values will be
automatically removed with a warning. If na.rm = TRUE is supplied
to the statistic, the warning will be suppressed.
ec: remove_missing(df, na.rm = FALSE, vars = names(df), name = "", finite = FALSE)

d:
scale_linewidth scales the width of lines and polygon strokes. Due to
historical reasons, it is also possible to control this with the size
aesthetic, but using linewidth is encourage to clearly differentiate area
aesthetics from stroke width aesthetics.

geom_segment() draws a straight line between points (x, y) and
(xend, yend). geom_curve() draws a curved line. See the underlying
drawing function grid::curveGrob() for the parameters that
control the curve.
ec: geom_segment(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "identity", position = "identity", ..., arrow = NULL, arrow.fill = NULL, lineend = "butt", linejoin = "round", na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
Most aesthetics are mapped from variables found in the data.
Sometimes, however, you want to delay the mapping until later in the
rendering process. ggplot2 has three stages of the data that you can map
aesthetics from, and three functions to control at which stage aesthetics
should be evaluated.
ec: stage(start = NULL, after_stat = NULL, after_scale = NULL)

Maps each level to an evenly spaced hue on the colour wheel.
It does not generate colour-blind safe palettes.
ec: scale_color_hue(name = waiver(), ..., h = c(0, 360) + 15, c = 100, l = 65, h.start = 0, direction = 1, na.value = "grey50", aesthetics = "colour")

d:
There are two types of bar charts: geom_bar() and geom_col().
geom_bar() makes the height of the bar proportional to the number of
cases in each group (or if the weight aesthetic is supplied, the sum
of the weights). If you want the heights of the bars to represent values
in the data, use geom_col() instead. geom_bar() uses stat_count() by
default: it counts the number of cases at each x position. geom_col()
uses stat_identity(): it leaves the data as is.
ec: geom_col(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, position = "stack", ..., just = 0.5, width = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

d:
translate_shape_string() is a helper function for translating point shapes
given as a character vector into integers that are interpreted by the
grid system.

These are complete themes which control all non-data display. Use

customized for individual geoms by providing a geom with the key_glyph
argument (see layer() or examples below.)

d:

<U+2060>scale_*_log10()<U+2060>, <U+2060>scale_*_sqrt()<U+2060> and <U+2060>scale_*_reverse()<U+2060>.

scale_x_binned() and scale_y_binned() are scales that discretize
continuous position data. You can use these scales to transform continuous
inputs before using it with a geom that requires discrete positions. An
example is using scale_x_binned() with geom_bar() to create a histogram.
ec: scale_y_binned(name = waiver(), n.breaks = 10, nice.breaks = TRUE, breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(), limits = NULL, expand = waiver(), oob = squish, na.value = NA_real_, right = TRUE, show.limits = FALSE, transform = "identity", trans = deprecated(), guide = waiver(), position = "left")

geom_smooth() and stat_smooth() are effectively aliases: they
both use the same arguments. Use stat_smooth() if you want to
display the results with a non-standard geom.
ec: geom_smooth(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "smooth", position = "identity", ..., method = NULL, formula = NULL, se = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

convenient when you draw an sf object as geoms like text and labels (so
geom_sf_text() and geom_sf_label() relies on this).

The resolution is the smallest non-zero distance between adjacent
values.  If there is only one unique value, then the resolution is defined
to be one. If x is an integer vector, then it is assumed to represent a
discrete variable, and the resolution is 1.

ec: coord_quickmap(xlim = NULL, ylim = NULL, expand = TRUE, clip = "on")

d:
+ is the key to constructing sophisticated ggplot2 graphics. It
allows you to start simple, then get more and more complex, checking your
work at each step.

d:
Visualise the distribution of a single continuous variable by dividing
the x axis into bins and counting the number of observations in each bin.
Histograms (geom_histogram()) display the counts with bars; frequency
polygons (geom_freqpoly()) display the counts with lines. Frequency
polygons are more suitable when you want to compare the distribution
across the levels of a categorical variable.
ec: geom_freqpoly(mapping = NULL, data = NULL, stat = "bin", position = "identity", ..., na.rm = FALSE, show.legend = NA, inherit.aes = TRUE)

ec: guide_axis_logticks(long = 2.25, mid = 1.5, short = 0.75, prescale.base = NULL, negative.small = 0.1, short.theme = element_line(), expanded = TRUE, cap = "none", theme = NULL, prescale_base = deprecated(), negative_small = deprecated(), short_theme = deprecated(), ...)
